thread.title: Trump supporters voice their approval
thread.title_full: Trump supporters voice their approval - The Boston Globe

author: bostonglobe
title: Trump supporters voice their approval
text:
Google+
Carolyn Kaster/Associated Press
President Donald Trump.
By Nicole Fleming Globe Correspondent February 05, 2017
Support for President Trump’s executive order on immigration may not be quite as loud in Massachusetts, an overwhelmingly blue state, as it is in other areas of the country — but it’s there.
“A temporary pause from seven countries is not a ‘Muslim ban,’ ” said Dean Cavaretta, former state director for Trump’s primary campaign. “I’d like to see to see our Congress, instead of running to a microphone, work to solve the larger problem.”
Advertisement
Those seven countries listed in the executive order, he said, were originally noted as potential problems by the Obama administration.
Cavaretta said that while he doesn’t want to see students affected by the executive order, there are very real and immediate safety and financial concerns regarding this country’s immigration situation.
Get Fast Forward in your inbox: Forget yesterday's news. Get what you need today in this early-morning email. Sign Up Thank you for signing up! Sign up for more newsletters here “We have illegal immigrants who are being charged with crimes, sitting in our county jails right now,” said Cavaretta. He said he works as a social worker for a county sheriff.
“Nobody wants to stop the best and brightest from coming to our schools,” he said. “They’re not the issue. It’s keeping us safe from people who are not being vetted, who are coming from places where terrorism has occurred.”
Arege Pascucci of Middleton, who attended the inauguration, said she is frequently taken into a room and asked questions when she goes to visit a property she owns in the Bahamas. She believes that just as she is vetted when visiting another country, America has a responsibility to its citizens to vet visitors.
Advertisement
“I understand the country’s policies and I’m not offended by it whatsoever,” she said. “... I follow the rules that are expected of me.”
Steve Boyson of Dennis, who works in construction, views Trump as a successful businessman who is following through on his promises — big promises, and therefore big actions.
As an old wise man once told me, ‘We’ll be talking about this man for the next 20,000 years for what he did today,’ ” he said.
The actions that sparked protests across the country are seen by Trump supporters as evidence that the president says what he means and does what he says.
“President Trump is doing exactly what he campaigned on,” said Janet Fogarty, a state committee woman for the Massachusetts Republican Party and a delegate for Trump. “It’s what people voted for. It’s why he won the election.”
Fogarty said she wishes more attention were being paid to the “temporary” aspect of the order, and doesn’t understand the widespread outrage. Contrary to Trump being seen as anti-immigration, she sees him as pro-immigration — he just wants the right immigrants who have been sufficiently investigated, she said.
“He always said he would impose extreme vetting of people coming into the country, especially people from countries that have been hostile to us,” said Fogarty. “... He doesn’t just talk.”
Nicole Fleming can be reached at nicole.fleming@globe.com .
